Description: Body sherd of Corinthian black-figured pottery closed vessel, probably a large alabastron; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting most probably of the neck and wing of a cock or other bird to right possibly part of bird wing; from top, close-spaced vertical lines (neck feathers?); below left, incised lines (tail feathers?) with added red dab between two of them; to the right black area with broad red zigzag bordered on each side by a row of added white dots between incised lines; on the right, possibly part of the wing in red; at top left, part of probable filling ornament.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
For a parallel, see Payne 1931, pl. 36, no. 12 (catalogue, no. 1225).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.150) (Phase 1)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
